description.p: A SaaS implementation build on top of the CSP IaaS supporting audit events.
An example of three customers leveraging an authorized SaaS, which is running on an authorized IaaS.
In this example, the IaaS SSP specifies customer responsibilities for certain controls.
The SaaS must address these for the control to be fully satisfied.
The SaaS provider may either implement these directly, or pass the responsiblity on to their customers. Often both are necessary.
For any given control, the IaaS SSP must describe:

ol.li: HOW the IaaS is directly satisfying the control
WHAT responsibilities are left for the IaaS customer to implement. (The IaaS customer is the SaaS.)

ol.li: WHAT is being inherited from the underlying IaaS
HOW the SaaS is directly satisfying the control.
WHAT responsibilities are left for the SaaS customer to implement. (The SaaS customers are Cust-A, B and C)

description.p: Inherits the centralized logging component from IaaS, including it's audit failure handling.
All virtualized components communicate with the IaaS-provided centralized logging server and the SaaS SOC via a private, dedicated administrative network.
Virtualized web servers are configured to alert the SaaS SOC Team, if they are unable to trnasmit logs..
If virtualized web servers lose network connectivity (thus are unable to notify the SaaS SOC), their off-line status will be recognized and alerted as described in control XX-#..
Virtualized databases are configured to alert the SaaS SOC Team, if they are unable to trnasmit logs..
If virtualized databases lose network connectivity (thus are unable to notify the SaaS SOC), their off-line status will be recognized and alerted as described in control XX-#..

As described in the SaaS Audit, Logging, and Incident Response Procedure, the SaaS SOC Team will allert each customer's designated POC of any logging outages that impact a customer's ability to meet logging requirements.
Each virtual component logs any audit log failures within its datastores if possible.

Each virtual component stores logs locally until the centralized logging capability is restored. In the event of reaching local log capacity each virtual component is configured to overwrite the oldest logs first.

The SaaS customer must ensure an appropriate POC is designed in the customer portal for notifications of audit failure.
